Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the modeling of plasticity in polycrystals using crystal plasticity models.
Question_1.Question: What is the standard way of modeling plasticity in polycrystals?
Question_1.A: Using a single crystal model for each grain
Question_1.C: Ignoring grain boundaries in the model
Question_1.Source: The standard way of modeling plasticity in polycrystals is by using the crystal plasticity model for single crystals in each grain...

Question_2.Context: The paper introduces a diffuse-interface crystal plasticity model for polycrystalline materials.
Question_2.Question: What is the main advantage of the diffuse-interface crystal plasticity model?
Question_2.B: It allows for the modeling of grain boundary processes
Question_2.C: It eliminates the need for boundary conditions
Question_2.D: It focuses only on single crystal behavior
Question_2.Source: The aim of this paper is to present a framework that preserves the ability to model intra-grain plasticity, while at the same time enabling a straightforward generalization to include grain boundary processes...

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the evolution of crystallographic texture in polycrystalline materials.
Question_3.Question: Why is the study of texture evolution important in polycrystals?
Question_3.A: To understand the chemical composition of the material
Question_3.B: To predict the mechanical properties of the material
Question_3.C: To determine the color of the material
Question_3.D: To study the electrical conductivity of the material
Question_3.Source: The study of texture evolution is important because textured metals typically exhibit plastic anisotropy, which plays a significant role on mechanical properties...

Question_4.Context: The paper discusses the decomposition of the deformation gradient into lattice and plastic parts.
Question_4.Question: What is the purpose of decomposing the deformation gradient into lattice and plastic parts?
Question_4.B: To separate the effects of dislocation slip and lattice deformation
Question_4.C: To eliminate the need for boundary conditions
Question_4.D: To focus only on the macroscopic stress-strain response
Question_4.Source: For single crystals, a multiplicative kinematic decomposition of the deformation gradient into elastic and plastic parts is typically used. This decomposition adequately describes the distinctly different kinematical mechanisms that operate during the plastic deformation of a crystal...

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the construction of a stress-free polycrystal by imposing specific initial conditions.
Question_5.Question: How is a stress-free polycrystal constructed in the model?
Question_5.A: By applying a constant stress to each grain
Question_5.B: By imposing a piecewise constant rotation field and its transpose
Question_5.C: By ignoring the effects of dislocation slip
Question_5.Source: To make the resulting model numerically tractable, we regularize the piecewise constant rotation field, resulting in a diffuse interface model, that preserves the zero-stress character of the grain boundaries...

Question_6.B: It allows for the modeling of grain boundary energies

Question_6.D: It eliminates the need for initial conditions

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the modeling of polycrystal plasticity with grain boundary evolution.
Question_7.Question: How does the diffuse-interface model enable the modeling of grain boundary processes?
Question_7.A: By ignoring the effects of grain boundaries
Question_7.B: By representing grain boundaries as geometrically necessary dislocations
Question_7.C: By using a continuum plasticity model
Question_7.D: By focusing only on single crystal behavior
Question_7.Source: To this end, we develop a 'diffuse'-interface crystal plasticity model for polycrystalline materials based on a representation of grain boundaries as a special subclass of geometrically necessary dislocations...
